The Chiefs of Staff gave the following reports in amplrficar-tion of the information contained in Cabinet War Room RecordsNos. 485 to 487 :- ;/,The attack on Bremen the previous night, in. which133 heavy and 15 medium bombers had been engaged, appearedfrom preliminary reports to have been highly successful. no british aircraft had been lost during the operation, but3 Wellingtons manned by Polish crews had crashed on landing.Two of the crews had been killed.An interesting report had been received from General Heywoodon conditions on the Greek Front. Notwithstanding the veryrigorous conditions, which caused some frostbite, the Greek army were in very good heart.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.Blockade Policy.France.(previous reference:W.M. The Chief of Naval Staff reported that an Eastboundconvoy of four French merchant ships, including the Chantilly(9,986 tons), escorted by the armed trawler La Toulonnaise, hadbeen intercepted off the Spanish Moroccan Coast outside territorial waters by, five.of our destroyers, and was being escorted back to gibraltar. The trawler had protested, and had reported inter-ception by wireless telegraphy, but had been allowed to proceed toOr an. The Chantilly had, contrary to International Law, offeredsome resistance (it was not clear of what character) to our boardingparty and one of our destroyers had fired a few rounds of machine-gun fire into the water. Unfortunately, these rounds had richo-chetted and had resulted in two civilians being killed and fourwounded.After discussion the War Cabinet decided as follows : (1) The Foreign Secretary was invited to send a message atonce to the Vichy authorities, without waiting for more complete information as to the nature of the resistance offered by the Chantilly, expressing greatregret at the casualties which had taken place, butpointing out that they must be regarded as theresult of this vessel s illegal action.(2) Notwithstanding this clash, the First Lord of theAdmiralty was invited to give intructioiis that further interceptions should, if possible, be made during the next two days.Franoe: Pro- 3. He had given the15th February as the approximate date on which the Bill wouldbecome law. It ought to be possible, however, to make appropria-tions under the existing law, in order to enable us to make day-to-day payments under our contracts in the interim period. (40) 493). . .. - . r.: wThe Chancellor of the Exchequer said that the essential features of the policy now proposed were contained in paragraphs1 and 2 of this Minute. We should cease to provide Eire with any facilities for obtaining shipping. Eire would be released from itsundertaking to charter only through us and would be free to charterin the open market. In actual fact, they would.be unable to do this,as our Allies do not make charters without previous consultationwith us.The Prime Minister said that, when the Eire Government was informed of what we proposed to do, it should be emphasised thatthis step was taken in no vindictive spirit and only dire- necessityforced us into such a step. . ,WM'te"--The War Cabinet agreed as follows : (a) Effect should be given forthwith to the proposals containedin the Chancellor of the Exchequer's Minute to thePrime Minister.(&) We should continue to allow any Eirean or neutral shipsengaged on Eire trade to receive the protection of ourconvoys. tv.;.:(c) When we informed the Eire Government that we: were unable to charter ships for them, no reference should bemade to insurance, but for the moment;! ;w?e - shouldcontinue to give facilities in this direction, ^n,(d) Subject to the special requirements of particular; Britishtrades (e.g., Welsh coal) we should withdraw vesselsengaged in traffic between this country and Eire as ourown needs might require.(e) The policy in regard to the regulation of food supplies to eire should be one of gradual diminution. Thus weshould not cut off all supplies of tea at once, but shouldcontinue to supply Eire with small quantities for thepresent.(/) The Minister of Information should inform the press thatthe Government viewed this measure with" pirdfblindregret, and that it had been taken only because1 "the pressure on our own shipping space was so severe.1 )(g) The Secretary of State for Dominion Affairs should beresponsible for the general handling of this'matter-'1 andother Departments concerned should keep in 'toueh- with. him. liUwM(h) The United Kingdom Representative to Eire should beinformed of the steps proposed, before action on theabove lines was initiated. In answer to a question, the Minister said that it was necessaryvp . -to ration pork and offals in order that poor people might be able toobtain them. He was fully aware of the importance of cheese in the diet of manual workers, and was already distributing cheese in larger quantities to industrial areas and taking the risk of other areas going short.It was suggested that when the reduction of the ration was announced, attention should be called in the Press to the fact that even the reduced meat ration was considerably above the 1918 ration.Emphasis might also be laid on the success that had attended the rationing system during the war, and to the complete absence offood queues.The War Cabinet agreed that the meat ration should bereduced to Is. The financial and thetechnical problems involved were more important, and the onlypeople who had experience of them were serving in the Ministry of aircraft Production.The Minister of Aircraft Production said that he and his stafffound it difficult to be responsible for an undertaking in which theydid not believe.It was further suggested that it was important that thereshould be a single controlling authority, responsible for the oil production in this country.The War Cabinet-Invited the Lord President of the Council to find a solution; for. this matter, consistent with the principle that a sin ""controlling authority: should be responsible for oil production in this; country. - ; Man-Power. 12. The Prime Minister contrasted the total strength of the Armywith the effective fighting strength of the Divisions at presentformed. He hoped that means would be found to avoid a furtherintake of men into the Army for the present. He hoped that theresults of the investigations now being carried out by the War office would soon be available, and that a decision on the matter could bereached quite soon. In the meantime, he suggested that considerationof the present Paper might be deferred.The Home Secretary and Minister of Home Security reminded the War Cabinet that he had been authorised to arrange for the drafting of a Bill for recruitment for the Civil Defence Services, inthe expectation that some proportion of the men called up under theAct would be available for Civil Defence. He also wished to put iton record that a number of Local Government Staffs and employeeswere of great value for Civil Defence purposes. He would com-municate on this matter with the Minister of Labour and NationalService.The War Cabinet-Postponed consideration of the Minister of Labour's Memo-randum for a short period, pending the enquiry, referredto by the Prime Minister, whether better use could be madeof the man-power already serving in the Army.Radio. 13. (G) (40) 327).skllled The Chancellor of the Duchy gave the following particulars in personnel. amplification of his Report :-(1) The Prime Minister had twice put radio work in the highestorder of priority. He (the Chancellor of the Duchy) hadscrupulously adhered to this, and his endeavours hadbeen directed to making sure that the supply of apparatus and of skilled personnel marched in step.(2) Good progress was being made with the scheme for obtain-ing specially trained Officers from the Universities.(3) About 30 Technical Colleges were now giving selected menalready in the Services a solid foundation of electricalknowledge.(4) The Radio Manufacturers were helping in a scheme forcombing the Services for personnel with qualifications for this work.(5) The comments of our Charge d'Affaires at Washingtonhad now been received on a plan for Obtaining skilled men from the United States of America. He advised that the best plan would be to get the Canadian Govern-ment to move in the matter. He (the Chancellor of the duchy of Lancaster) had investigated the question withthe Dominions Secretary, and might ask for the PrimeMinister5 s help in this matter.The Prime Minister said that the War Cabinet were muchindebted to the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster for the valuable work he was doing in this matter.
